course.subject: ENVR
course.name: Introduction to Atmospheric Science
course.description: The course mainly consists of two parts: atmospheric physics and atmospheric chemistry. Atmospheric physics topics include evolution of the earth’s atmosphere, introduction to the atmospheric structure, composition, dynamics, thermodynamics, circulation, and weather patterns. Atmospheric chemistry topics include tropospheric chemistry, air pollution chemistry and toxicity, greenhouse gases and climate change, stratospheric chemistry and ozone depletion. For EVMT students and students with consent from the course instructor only.
course.prerequisites: (CIVL 1140 OR ENVR 2010 OR LIFS 1030 OR PHYS 1003) AND (MATH 1003 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1018 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1023)

reviews.comment_teaching:
The lectures were quite interesting. He took the time to explain each of the concepts and went into their derivation. It was quite interesting, especially if you're interested in the physics behind the phenomena being discussed.

The TAs and the professor respond quickly to any emails and that helped a lot, since some concepts can be a bit tricky to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% participation: No discussions, I guess you just need to show up for class

40% HW assignments: Project on octave. The HW is quite simple and most of the time the main concept is already in the PPT.

50% Final Exam: Divided into MCQs (70 points) and long answers (30 points).

The mean for HW assignment is normally around 4/5. You can get extra credit if you finish the HW during the lab time
reviews.comment_workload:
It's a decent amount of work for a 3000 level course. One HW assignment almost every week. But you can finish that in class. Otherwise, there is just 1 final, for which reading the lecture slides and notes is more than enough.

Also, you might want to work on the sample paper he uploads as that helps a lot in the end.
